content: hi @T-compiler/meeting , the planning meeting for this cycle is starting now
the list of proposals is here
we have just one new proposal: "1.52 Fingerprint retrospective (aka COE)” compiler-team#435
I do think there are other things we could dedicate a Friday meeting to, such as reviewing the outstanding MCPs, or figuring out what to do with our P-medium+P-high issue backlog
but for this cycle, I’m completely happy with just one meeting. :)

I suppose the main thing I want to do is 1. make sure that people are generally in favor of dedicating a friday meeting to compiler-team#435, and 2. double-check whether the list of items to cover (in the associated document) is sufficient, or if people think it might be missing something

specifically, compiler-team#435 says (in its summary):

The compiler team should have a retrospective on the 1.52.0 release issues with fingerprints that led to an emergency release of 1.52.1. @pnkfelix will take lead on preparing a document discussing 1. the events in our development and release process that led to the issues in the 1.52.0 release, 2. how we subsequently discovered the issues and responded to them in the short-term, and 3. what steps we can take going forward to reduce risk of re-occurrence of similar events in the future.
So there's only the one proposal?
Yeah, that’s all
OK
you want to propose something?
it's a good one though :)
I wanted to propose something similar
I definitely won’t have time next week to prepare the doc
I do have concerns about our lint level flags story, but no time to drive the effort/discussion.
i.e. discussing how we can get more testing if those tests are bad for performance
so the earliest I would expect to have a meeting for compiler-team#435 would be Friday June 18th
I'm also out next week
I have thoughts about testing too
I hadn’t really thought hard about whether more testing would have caught this
in particular, we knew about these ICEs
I think the main problem was that we didn't realize when it was going to be released
Right
yes, testing might be a related but different topic
which is something I think the release team has discussed as well

Aaron Hill said:

I think the main problem was that we didn't realize when it was going to be released

I think that wasn't the only problem
I can imagine ways that more testing could have caught this problem
e.g. if we had a policy of putting in “expected fail” or “expected ICE” tests
I don't think we should do the retro right now though :)
right right
good point @nikomatsakis
but anyway, @mw , I think it would be great if you could put together a proposal for the next cycle
with your thoughts around testing
the main thing i want to resolve
Oh, well, three main things
1. should we have a Friday meeting for compiler-team#435 (and it sounds like people are not opposed to it)
1. does the current summary for compiler-team#435 hit all the points we would want the document to cover (i.e. is it sufficiently broad in scope)
1. Which Friday to have the meeting!
It could be on either :one: June 16th 18th or :two: June 23rd 25th
those are wednesdays, right?
omg
/me was messing with their calendar and advanced it to July without noticing
Looks like people are in favor of Friday June 18th.
Great, I’ll write up an Inside Rust announcing the meeting
anything else people want to discuss? We’ve got a release in ~two weeks
where are we standing with the fingerprint issues for the next release?
we have decided to give it another cycle, right?
The plan, based on last Friday’s discussion, is to do the same thing in 1.53 stable that we did in 1.52.1
yeah
but we won’t put it into the 1.53-beta nor the 1.54-beta
:+1:
So there’s a slight risk associated with having the deviation between the beta and the stable
but I think its the best option available
(because I do not want to regress incr-comp defaulting to “on” atop the beta branch, for those (admittedly few, according to twitter poll) who are using beta branch.)

@simulacrum what is the best way to coordinate ensuring that that happens? I guess it would be good to put the code into beta but have it turned off via a boolean switch or cfg! flag, just to make the final step of turning it on in stable trivial?
hm, I think the patch is easy enough we can just land it as part of the uplift
but then again the patch itself is pretty trivial
It'd be good to file an issue and milestone it
yeah okay
that way it's on our radar when making the release
Okay I’ll file an issue, very good point
Okay then. I think we can just end in the meeting in that case!
Thank you everyone in @T-compiler/meeting for attending!
